PHYSICS.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
031 PHYSICS
(For both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of Sections A, B and C.
2. Answer all questions in the spaces provided.
3. Section A carries 16 marks, Section B 60 marks, Section C 24 marks.
4. Show all working clearly.
5. All writing must be in blue or black ink; diagrams in pencil.
6. Calculators and phones are not allowed.
7. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.
8. Where necessary, use: g = 10 m/s², density of water = 1000 kg/m³.

SECTION A (16 Marks)
1. Multiple Choice Questions (1 mark each)
(i) SI unit of force is
- A. Joule
- B. Newton
- C. Watt
- D. Pascal

(ii) Acceleration is defined as
- A. rate of change of displacement
- B. rate of change of velocity
- C. distance per unit time
- D. change in mass

(iii) A concave mirror produces a real, inverted image when the object is placed
- A. at focus
- B. at pole
- C. beyond centre of curvature
- D. between pole and focus

(iv) Direct change from solid to gas is called
- A. melting
- B. evaporation
- C. sublimation
- D. condensation

(v) Instrument to measure current is
- A. voltmeter
- B. ammeter
- C. ohmmeter
- D. galvanometer

(vi) SI unit of energy is
- A. Joule
- B. Watt
- C. Pascal
- D. Newton

(vii) Time period of a simple pendulum is
- A. frequency
- B. period
- C. amplitude
- D. phase

(viii) Bending of light from one medium to another is
- A. reflection
- B. refraction
- C. diffraction
- D. interference

2. Match the following (1 mark each)
List A
(i) Archimedes’ principle
(ii) Hooke’s law
(iii) Law of conservation of energy
(iv) Coulomb’s law
(v) Law of reflection

List B
A. Extension of spring ∝ applied force within elastic limit
B. Angle of incidence = angle of reflection
C. Upthrust = weight of fluid displaced
D. Energy cannot be created or destroyed
E. Force between charges ∝ product of charges / distance²

SECTION B (60 Marks)
3. Define work in physics and calculate the work done when a force of 30 N moves an object 4 m in the direction of force.

4. State Newton's second law of motion and calculate acceleration and net force if mass = 500 kg, final velocity = 15 m/s, time = 5 s.

5. Define specific heat capacity. Calculate heat needed to raise 3 kg of water from 25°C to 75°C (c = 4200 J/kg°C).

6. Draw a labelled series circuit with battery, resistor, ammeter and switch. State two safety precautions when handling electricity.

7. Explain why objects float or sink using density and buoyancy. A wooden block (mass 12 kg, volume 0.02 m³) is placed in water. Determine whether it floats and calculate upthrust.

8. Define efficiency of a machine and calculate if useful work = 1800 J, energy supplied = 2400 J.

9. Difference between series and parallel resistors in current and voltage. Three resistors (R1 = 3 Ω, R2 = 6 Ω, R3 = 9 Ω) in series across 36 V battery. Calculate total resistance and current.

10. Explain image formed by convex lens when object is between focal point and lens. Draw a labelled ray diagram.

SECTION C (24 Marks)
11. (a) Describe experiment to find focal length of convex lens using distant object and screen.
    (b) Distance measured between lens and screen = 30 cm. Determine focal length.
    (c) State three characteristics of image when object is beyond 2F.

PAnswers.content:
SECTION A
1. Multiple Choice Answers
(i) B. Newton — Force is measured in Newton (N) which is kg·m/s².
(ii) B. Rate of change of velocity — Acceleration = Δv / Δt.
(iii) C. Beyond centre of curvature — Produces real, inverted image.
(iv) C. Sublimation — Direct solid to gas change.
(v) B. Ammeter — Measures electric current; connected in series.
(vi) A. Joule — SI unit of energy, work done in joules.
(vii) B. Period — Time for one complete oscillation.
(viii) B. Refraction — Bending of light when passing between media.

2. Matching
(i) C; (ii) A; (iii) D; (iv) E; (v) B

SECTION B
3. Work
Definition: Work = force × displacement along direction of force.
Calculation: W = 30 × 4 = 120 J.

4. Newton's 2nd Law
F_net = m a, a = Δv / Δt = 15 / 5 = 3 m/s²
F_net = 500 × 3 = 1500 N

5. Specific Heat Capacity
Definition: Heat needed to raise 1 kg by 1°C.
Q = m c ΔT = 3 × 4200 × (75 - 25) = 630,000 J

6. Circuit diagram: battery (+,-), resistor (R), ammeter (A) in series, switch; safety: switch off before connecting, do not touch live wires.

7. Buoyancy
Density block = 12 / 0.02 = 600 kg/m³ < water 1000 kg/m³ → floats
Upthrust = ρ V g = 1000 × 0.02 × 10 = 200 N
Weight = 12 × 10 = 120 N → floats

8. Efficiency
η = (useful work / energy supplied) ×100% = 1800/2400 ×100 = 75%

9. Series vs Parallel
Series: current same, voltage divides; Parallel: voltage same, current divides
Total resistance: 3+6+9=18 Ω
Current: I = V/R = 36/18 = 2 A

10. Convex lens, object between F and lens
Image is virtual, erect, magnified; cannot project on screen; diagram: rays diverge through lens, extended backwards to meet for virtual image.

SECTION C
11. Focal length experiment
(a) Place lens, screen; point at distant object; move screen until sharp image appears; measure distance = f.
(b) Measured distance = 30 cm → focal length f = 30 cm
(c) Object beyond 2F: image real, inverted, reduced in size, located between F and 2F.

CHEMISTRY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
032 CHEMISTRY – THEORY PAPER 1
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C, answer only one (1) question.
3. Write all answers clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Use correct chemical symbols and formulae.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.
   (i) The SI unit of mass is
   - A. Newton
   - B. Kilogram
   - C. Gram
   - D. Mole

   (ii) Which of the following is a compound?
   - A. Na
   - B. O2
   - C. H2O
   - D. Cl2

   (iii) The main constituent of air responsible for respiration is
   - A. Oxygen
   - B. Nitrogen
   - C. Carbon dioxide
   - D. Hydrogen

   (iv) Which of the following is a neutral oxide?
   - A. CO2
   - B. N2O
   - C. SO2
   - D. Na2O

   (v) An acid is a substance that
   - A. Accepts protons
   - B. Donates protons
   - C. Accepts electrons
   - D. Neutralizes bases

   (vi) The process of converting a liquid to a gas at a temperature below boiling point is called
   - A. Evaporation
   - B. Condensation
   - C. Sublimation
   - D. Freezing

   (vii) A base reacts with an acid to produce
   - A. Water only
   - B. Salt only
   - C. Salt and water
   - D. Gas

   (viii) Which of the following is an example of a covalent molecule?
   - A. NaCl
   - B. H2
   - C. KBr
   - D. MgO

   (ix) The energy change when 1 mole of substance is completely burnt in oxygen is called
   - A. Enthalpy of formation
   - B. Enthalpy of combustion
   - C. Activation energy
   - D. Heat capacity

   (x) Filtration is used to
   - A. Separate insoluble solid from liquid
   - B. Separate liquids with different boiling points
   - C. Separate soluble solids from solution
   - D. Separate gases

2. Match the items in List A with correct responses in List B.
   List A
   (i) Rusting
   (ii) Titration
   (iii) Atomic number
   (iv) Electroplating
   (v) Mole

   List B
   A. Number of protons in nucleus
   B. Chemical reaction of iron with water and oxygen
   C. Quantity of substance containing 6.02 × 10^23 particles
   D. Coating metal with another metal using electricity
   E. Determining concentration of a solution

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define an element and give three examples.
   (b) Explain the difference between elements and compounds.

4. (a) Explain how hydrogen gas can be prepared in the laboratory using zinc and dilute sulfuric acid.
   (b) Write the balanced chemical equation.

5. (a) Define solvent and solute.
   (b) Describe how to prepare a saturated solution of potassium nitrate.

6. (a) State the law of definite proportions.
   (b) 10 g of water is formed from 8 g of oxygen. Find the mass of hydrogen.

7. (a) Explain two differences between ionic and covalent bonding.
   (b) Draw a dot-and-cross diagram of HCl molecule.

8. (a) Define electrolysis.
   (b) Explain what happens at the cathode and anode during electrolysis of copper(II) sulfate solution using copper electrodes.

9. (a) Explain three methods of preventing corrosion of metals.
   (b) Describe why coating with grease or oil helps prevent corrosion.

10. (a) Describe the difference between a concentrated and dilute acid.
     (b) Suggest two indicators used to distinguish acids from bases.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer only one question.

11. (a) Explain the steps for preparing 250 cm³ of 0.5 M hydrochloric acid from concentrated HCl.
     (b) State three safety precautions to observe during preparation.

12. (a) Describe the laboratory method to determine the melting point of a solid.
     (b) Suggest how impurities affect the melting point of a substance.

SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Kilogram — SI unit of mass is kilogram (kg).
(ii) C. H2O — H2O is a compound consisting of two elements, H and O.
(iii) A. Oxygen — Oxygen is essential for respiration.
(iv) B. N2O — Nitrous oxide is neutral; CO2 and SO2 are acidic, Na2O is basic.
(v) B. Donates protons — Acids are proton donors (Brønsted–Lowry definition).
(vi) A. Evaporation — Evaporation occurs below boiling point.
(vii) C. Salt and water — Neutralization reaction produces salt and water.
(viii) B. H2 — Covalent bond involves sharing of electrons; H2 is diatomic covalent.
(ix) B. Enthalpy of combustion — Heat released when 1 mole of substance burns in oxygen.
(x) A. Separate insoluble solid from liquid — Filtration removes undissolved particles.

2. Matching answers:
(i) B — Rusting: chemical reaction of iron with water and oxygen.
(ii) E — Titration: determining concentration of a solution.
(iii) A — Atomic number: number of protons in nucleus.
(iv) D — Electroplating: coating metal with another metal using electricity.
(v) C — Mole: quantity of substance containing 6.02 × 10^23 particles.

SECTION B

3. (a) Element: substance made of only one type of atom. Examples: Oxygen (O), Sodium (Na), Carbon (C).
(b) Elements consist of single atoms; compounds consist of two or more elements chemically combined.

4. (a) Zinc reacts with dilute sulfuric acid producing hydrogen gas. Procedure: Add small pieces of zinc to dilute H2SO4 in a flask and collect evolved gas over water.
(b) Zn + H2SO4 → ZnSO4 + H2 ↑

5. (a) Solvent: substance that dissolves solute. Solute: substance that dissolves in solvent.
(b) To prepare saturated solution: dissolve potassium nitrate in water at room temperature until no more dissolves; filter if necessary.

6. (a) Law of definite proportions: a chemical compound always contains elements in fixed ratio by mass.
(b) Water formed: 10 g; O = 8 g, H = 10-8 = 2 g.

7. (a) Differences: Ionic bonding involves transfer of electrons, forms crystalline solids, high melting points; covalent bonding involves sharing of electrons, can form gases or liquids, lower melting points.
(b) HCl dot-and-cross diagram: H shares 1 electron with Cl.

8. (a) Electrolysis: decomposition of an electrolyte using electricity.
(b) During electrolysis of CuSO4:
- Cathode: Cu2+ gains electrons to form copper metal.
- Anode: Copper metal loses electrons to form Cu2+.

9. (a) Preventing corrosion: painting, galvanising, sacrificial anode, coating with oil/grease.
(b) Grease/oil prevents contact with water/oxygen, slowing corrosion.

10. (a) Concentrated acid: high molarity of acid; dilute acid: low molarity.
(b) Indicators: Litmus, phenolphthalein, methyl orange.

SECTION C

11. (a) Steps: Calculate volume of concentrated HCl needed for 0.5 M solution; dilute to 250 cm³ with distilled water in a volumetric flask.
(b) Safety: wear goggles and gloves; add acid to water slowly; label the solution.

12. (a) Melting point determination: Place solid in capillary tube, heat gradually, observe temperature when solid melts.
(b) Impurities lower and broaden melting point range.

BIOLOGY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
034 BIOLOGY – THEORY PAPER 2
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C answer any two (2) questions.
3. Write all answers clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Use scientific names where necessary.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.

SECTION A (16 Marks)
Answer all questions.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) Which of the following is a prokaryotic organism?
   - A. Amoeba
   - B. Bacterium
   - C. Paramecium
   - D. Fungi

   (ii) The site of photosynthesis in plant cells is
   - A. Nucleus
   - B. Chloroplast
   - C. Mitochondria
   - D. Ribosome

   (iii) The human blood group that is universal donor is
   - A. AB
   - B. O
   - C. A
   - D. B

   (iv) Which hormone regulates blood sugar level?
   - A. Adrenaline
   - B. Insulin
   - C. Thyroxine
   - D. Growth hormone

   (v) The process by which water moves from roots to leaves is called
   - A. Osmosis
   - B. Transpiration
   - C. Diffusion
   - D. Photosynthesis

   (vi) Which part of the brain controls balance and coordination?
   - A. Medulla oblongata
   - B. Cerebrum
   - C. Cerebellum
   - D. Hypothalamus

   (vii) Gametes are produced by
   - A. Mitosis
   - B. Meiosis
   - C. Fertilization
   - D. Binary fission

   (viii) The excretory organ in humans is
   - A. Lungs
   - B. Kidneys
   - C. Heart
   - D. Liver

   (ix) The movement of molecules from high to low concentration is called
   - A. Active transport
   - B. Diffusion
   - C. Osmosis
   - D. Phagocytosis

   (x) Which of the following diseases is caused by deficiency of iodine?
   - A. Rickets
   - B. Goitre
   - C. Scurvy
   - D. Anaemia

2. Match the items in **List A** with **List B**.

   List A
   (i) Phloem
   (ii) Xylem
   (iii) Ligament
   (iv) Alveoli
   (v) Platelets

   List B
   A. Tissue transporting sugars from leaves to other parts
   B. Air sacs in lungs for gas exchange
   C. Tissue transporting water and minerals
   D. Blood component helping in clotting
   E. Connects bones to bones

BAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Bacterium — Prokaryotic cells lack nucleus and membrane-bound organelles.

(ii) B. Chloroplast — Site where photosynthesis occurs using chlorophyll.

(iii) B. O — Universal donor blood group because it has no A or B antigens.

(iv) B. Insulin — Lowers blood glucose by promoting uptake into cells.

(v) B. Transpiration — Loss of water vapor from leaves, helps water movement from roots.

(vi) C. Cerebellum — Controls coordination, posture, and balance.

(vii) B. Meiosis — Produces gametes with half the chromosome number.

(viii) B. Kidneys — Filter blood and excrete waste as urine.

(ix) B. Diffusion — Passive movement of molecules from high to low concentration.

(x) B. Goitre — Iodine deficiency leads to enlargement of thyroid gland.

2. Matching:

(i) A — Phloem transports sugars from leaves to other parts.
(ii) C — Xylem transports water and minerals from roots.
(iii) E — Ligaments connect bones to bones.
(iv) B — Alveoli are air sacs for gas exchange.
(v) D — Platelets help in blood clotting.

SECTION B (54 Marks)

3. Cell and structure
(a) Cell: Basic unit of life; smallest structure capable of independent life.
   Tissue: Group of cells performing a common function.
(b) Examples of tissues: epithelium, muscle, connective tissue.

4. Plant nutrition
(a) Photosynthesis: Process by which green plants use sunlight to make food from CO2 and water; general formula: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2.
(b) Factors affecting photosynthesis: light intensity, CO2 concentration, water availability, temperature.

5. Human anatomy
(a) Circulatory system: Heart pumps blood through arteries, veins, and capillaries.
(b) Heart chambers: 2 atria and 2 ventricles; valves prevent backflow.

6. Excretion and homeostasis
(a) Kidney structure: cortex, medulla, nephron, collecting duct.
(b) Function: filters blood, removes urea and other waste, maintains osmotic balance.

7. Reproduction
(a) Sexual reproduction: Fusion of gametes, produces genetically variable offspring.
(b) Meiosis ensures haploid gametes; fertilization restores diploid number.

8. Nervous system
(a) Neuron structure: dendrites, cell body, axon, myelin sheath.
(b) Impulse transmission: dendrites → cell body → axon → synapse → next neuron.

9. Transport in plants
(a) Xylem: transports water and minerals from roots to leaves; phloem: transports food.
(b) Mechanism: cohesion-tension theory for xylem; translocation via phloem.

10. Health and diseases
(a) Deficiency diseases: Vitamin A – night blindness; Iodine – goitre; Iron – anaemia.
(b) Preventive measures: balanced diet, supplementation, iodized salt.

SECTION C (30 Marks)

11. Laboratory work
(a) Microscopy: Use of microscope to observe plant/animal cells; stain to improve visibility.
(b) Precautions: handle slides carefully, clean lenses, avoid touching lenses.

12. Ecology
(a) Food chain example: grass → grasshopper → frog → snake → eagle.
(b) Energy flow: energy decreases at each trophic level; 10% rule.

13. Human physiology
(a) Digestive system: mouth → esophagus → stomach → small intestine → large intestine → anus.
(b) Function: breakdown of food, absorption of nutrients, elimination of waste.

GEOGRAPHY2.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
013 GEOGRAPHY – THEORY PAPER 2
(For Both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C, answer any TWO questions.
3. Write your Examination Number at the top right corner of every page.
4. All writing must be in blue or black ink.
5. Use the spaces provided for all your answers.

SECTION A (16 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer from among the given alternatives and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) The study of Earth’s atmosphere and weather phenomena is called
   - A. Geology
   - B. Meteorology
   - C. Oceanography
   - D. Cartography

   (ii) The natural movement of ocean water caused by wind is called
   - A. Tide
   - B. Ocean current
   - C. Tsunami
   - D. Waves

   (iii) The major cause of desertification is
   - A. Deforestation and overgrazing
   - B. Irrigation
   - C. Fertilizer use
   - D. Urbanisation

   (iv) Which of the following is an example of renewable energy?
   - A. Coal
   - B. Oil
   - C. Solar power
   - D. Natural gas

   (v) An equatorially located rainforest has
   - A. Low rainfall
   - B. High temperatures and high rainfall
   - C. Cold and dry climate
   - D. Low humidity

   (vi) The type of farming which depends on rainfall and uses manual tools is
   - A. Irrigation farming
   - B. Extensive mechanized farming
   - C. Subsistence farming
   - D. Plantation farming

   (vii) A map projection which shows true shape but distorts area is called
   - A. Conformal
   - B. Equal-area
   - C. Mercator
   - D. Robinson

   (viii) The zone where tectonic plates meet and earthquakes often occur is called
   - A. Crust
   - B. Fault line
   - C. Rift valley
   - D. Core

   (ix) Which of the following minerals is used for making cement?
   - A. Limestone
   - B. Gold
   - C. Diamond
   - D. Salt

   (x) The main cause of air pollution in urban areas is
   - A. Volcanic eruptions
   - B. Industrial emissions and vehicle exhaust
   - C. Deforestation
   - D. Overfishing

2. Match the items in List A with the correct responses in List B.

   List A
   (i) Contour lines
   (ii) GPS
   (iii) Renewable resources
   (iv) Drainage basin
   (v) Population census
   (vi) Field sketching

   List B
   A. Lines joining points of equal elevation
   B. System to determine exact location using satellites
   C. Natural resources that can be replenished
   D. Area drained by a river and its tributaries
   E. Official count of population and demographics
   F. Drawing simplified representation of landscape features

GAnswers2.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) B. Meteorology — Meteorology is the study of the atmosphere and weather phenomena. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(ii) B. Ocean current — Ocean currents are large-scale movement of water in the oceans caused by wind, temperature differences, and salinity. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(iii) A. Deforestation and overgrazing — These remove vegetation cover, leading to soil degradation and desertification. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(iv) C. Solar power — Solar energy is renewable because it is naturally replenished. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(v) B. High temperatures and high rainfall — Equatorial rainforests have hot and humid climates with heavy rainfall. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(vi) C. Subsistence farming — Relies on rainfall and manual tools to grow crops for family consumption. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(vii) A. Conformal — Conformal maps preserve shape but distort area. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(viii) B. Fault line — Earthquakes and volcanic activity occur along tectonic plate boundaries called fault lines. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(ix) A. Limestone — Limestone is a key raw material in cement production. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

(x) B. Industrial emissions and vehicle exhaust — Major sources of air pollution in urban areas. ([necta.go.tz](https://www.necta.go.tz))

2. Matching:

(i) A — Contour lines: show points of equal elevation.
(ii) B — GPS: provides exact location using satellites.
(iii) C — Renewable resources: resources that can be replenished naturally.
(iv) D — Drainage basin: area drained by a river and tributaries.
(v) E — Population census: official count of people and demographics.
(vi) F — Field sketching: simplified drawing of landscape features.

SECTION B (Sample Answers)

3. (a) Contour lines represent the shape and elevation of landforms. GPS gives accurate location for mapping.
(b) Renewable resources include solar energy, wind, and water, which can be used repeatedly.

4. (a) Drainage basin maps show rivers and tributaries; slope and watershed boundaries are indicated.
(b) Population census helps government plan services and allocate resources.

5. (a) Weather is short-term atmospheric conditions; climate is average weather over time.
(b) Desertification is caused by removal of vegetation and overgrazing; impacts include soil loss and reduced agricultural productivity.

6. (a) Equatorial rainforest has dense vegetation, hot temperatures, and high rainfall; supports diverse ecosystems.
(b) Human activities such as logging, mining, and clearing land for farming can damage forests.

SECTION C (Guideline Answers)

9. Field sketching: observe features, note elevations, rivers, roads, settlements; draw base map; label features. Instruments: compass, tape measure, clinometer.
10. Agriculture influenced by rainfall, soil fertility, temperature, and altitude. Transport aids movement of goods, access to markets, and economic development.
11. Soil erosion caused by deforestation, overgrazing, and improper farming. Control measures: planting trees, terracing, and mulching.

End of Answers.

BUSINESS_STUDIES.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
065 BUSINESS STUDIES – THEORY PAPER
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C answer only TWO (2) questions.
3. All writing must be done in blue or black ink.
4. Write your Examination Number at the top right corner of every page.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions.

1. For each of items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) Which of the following is a primary function of business?
   - A. Consumption
   - B. Production
   - C. Banking
   - D. Importing

   (ii) A document that shows goods sent and payment due from a buyer is called

   - C. Quotation

   (iii) A partnership is a business owned by
   - A. One person
   - B. Two or more persons

   - D. A board of directors

   (iv) Microfinance institutions mainly provide
   - A. Insurance
   - B. Small loans to poor entrepreneurs
   - C. Large corporate loans

   (v) Money used to start a business is called
   - A. Profit
   - B. Capital
   - C. Revenue
   - D. Wage

   (vi) The purpose of bookkeeping is to
   - A. Sell goods
   - B. Record financial transactions
   - C. Produce goods
   - D. Advertise

   (vii) A market where only a few sellers exist is called
   - A. Perfect competition
   - B. Monopoly
   - C. Oligopoly
   - D. Duopoly

   (viii) Business ethics refers to
   - A. Making maximum profit only
   - B. Moral principles in business activities
   - C. Marketing strategies
   - D. Financial accounting

   (ix) The term ‘entrepreneur’ refers to
   - A. A business consultant
   - B. Someone who organises and manages business
   - C. A supplier of goods
   - D. A government official

   (x) A cheque is
   - A. Credit note
   - B. Cash receipt
   - C. Order to bank to pay money
   - D. Invoice

2. Match the items in List A with the responses in List B.

   List A
   (i) Balance sheet
   (ii) Demand
   (iii) Entrepreneur
   (iv) Inventory
   (v) Advertisement

   List B
   A. Goods held for sale
   B. A statement showing financial position
   C. The desire and ability to buy goods
   D. Persuading customers to buy products
   E. Person who organises business resources

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions.

3. (a) Define *business*.
   (b) Explain three types of business activities.

4. (a) Distinguish between sole proprietorship and partnership.
   (b) Give two advantages of forming a partnership.

5. (a) Explain the concept of *capital* and *revenue*.
   (b) Differentiate between capital expenditure and revenue expenditure.

6. (a) What is marketing? Give two functions of marketing.
   (b) Explain the importance of customer service.

7. (a) Define supply and demand.
   (b) What happens to price when supply exceeds demand? Explain.

8. (a) Explain the importance of keeping business records.
   (b) Describe two types of business records.

9. (a) What are small and medium enterprises (SMEs)?
   (b) List three challenges faced by SMEs.

10. (a) Define *entrepreneurship*.
     (b) Explain two qualities of a successful entrepreneur.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer any TWO questions.

11. (a) Explain the role of banking in business.
     (b) Discuss three services provided by commercial banks.

12. (a) Describe how a business can use branding to increase sales.
     (b) Explain two advantages of advertising.

13. (a) Explain the concept of *business ethics*.
     (b) Describe three ethical practices in business.

BUAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers:
(i) B. Production — A primary function of business is production of goods/services.
(ii) B. Invoice — A document showing goods sold and amount due is an invoice.
(iii) B. Two or more persons — Partnership involves two or more persons.
(iv) B. Small loans to poor entrepreneurs — Microfinance institutions provide small loans.
(v) B. Capital — Money used to start a business is capital.
(vi) B. Record financial transactions — Bookkeeping records financial transactions.
(vii) C. Oligopoly — Few sellers in a market characterise oligopoly.
(viii) B. Moral principles in business activities — Business ethics covers moral conduct.
(ix) B. Someone who organises and manages business — Entrepreneur organises resources.
(x) C. Order to bank to pay money — Cheque instructs bank to pay.

2. Matching answers:
(i) B — Balance sheet is a statement showing financial position.
(ii) C — Demand is desire with ability to buy.
(iii) E — Entrepreneur organises business resources.
(iv) A — Inventory is goods held for sale.
(v) D — Advertisement persuades customers to buy.

SECTION B

3. (a) Business is any economic activity that involves production, distribution, and sale of goods and services to satisfy human needs for profit.
   (b) Three types of business activities: production (making goods), trading (buying and selling goods), and service (offering intangible services like transport, banking).

4. (a) Sole proprietorship is owned by one person; partnership is owned by two or more persons.
   (b) Advantages of partnership: shared capital and shared decision making.

5. (a) Capital refers to funds invested in business; revenue is income earned from sales.
   (b) Capital expenditure is money spent on assets (like machinery) while revenue expenditure is money spent on day-to-day operations (like wages).

6. (a) Marketing is the process of promoting and selling products; functions include market research and advertising.
   (b) Importance of customer service: improves customer satisfaction and encourages repeat business.

7. (a) Demand is quantity buyers are willing to buy; supply is quantity producers are willing to sell.
   (b) When supply exceeds demand, price tends to fall because surplus goods push sellers to lower prices.

8. (a) Business records are important for tracking performance and making financial decisions.
   (b) Types: sales records and purchase records.

9. (a) SMEs are small and medium sized businesses with limited scale of operations.
   (b) Challenges facing SMEs include lack of capital, competition, and poor infrastructure.

10. (a) Entrepreneurship is the process of starting and running a business.
     (b) Qualities of successful entrepreneur: creativity and risk taking.

SECTION C (Sample answers)

11. (a) The role of banking in business includes safekeeping funds, providing loans, and facilitating payments.
     (b) Services by commercial banks: savings and current accounts; loans and overdraft; fund transfers.

12. (a) A business uses branding by creating a unique name and logo to distinguish products.
     (b) Advantages of advertising: increases product awareness and attracts customers.

13. (a) Business ethics is conduct that guides moral behaviour in business operations.
     (b) Ethical practices: fair pricing, truthful advertising, good treatment of employees.

End of Answers.

HISTORY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
012 HISTORY PAPER 2
(For Both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in Sections A and B.
2. In Section C answer any three (3) questions.
3. All writing must be in blue or black ink.
4. Drawings and maps must be in pencil.
5. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.

SECTION A (20 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. (a) For each of items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer and write its letter beside the item number.
   (i) The main reason for European exploration in the 15th century was
   - A. To spread African culture
   - B. To discover new lands for settlement
   - C. To seek trade routes and resources
   - D. To form African alliances

   (ii) The Trans-Atlantic slave trade involved primarily
   - A. Europeans enslaving other Europeans
   - B. Africans enslaving Europeans
   - C. Africans captured and sent to the Americas
   - D. Asians being enslaved

   (iii) The Pan-African Congresses were aimed at
   - A. European colonial expansion
   - B. African unity and independence
   - C. Promoting slavery
   - D. Trade with Asia

   (iv) The first successful anti-colonial uprising in Tanzania was
   - A. Maji Maji Rebellion
   - B. Herero revolt
   - C. Mau Mau uprising
   - D. Zulu resistance

   (v) Indirect rule in colonial Africa was
   - A. Complete control by European administrators
   - B. Using local leaders to govern on behalf of colonial powers
   - C. Ignoring African systems entirely
   - D. Establishing settler colonies

   (vi) The famous nationalist leader of Kenya was
   - A. Kwame Nkrumah
   - B. Jomo Kenyatta
   - C. Julius Nyerere
   - D. Patrice Lumumba

   (vii) The main purpose of missionary education in colonial Africa was
   - A. To teach modern science only
   - B. To spread Christianity and literacy
   - C. To encourage rebellion
   - D. To create industrial workers only

   (viii) The Atlantic Charter of 1941 influenced African nationalism because it
   - A. Promoted colonial rule
   - B. Advocated self-determination and freedom
   - C. Supported apartheid
   - D. Enforced European alliances

   (ix) One major social effect of colonialism was
   - A. Unity among tribes
   - B. Introduction of Western education and religion
   - C. Eradication of all diseases
   - D. Equal land distribution

   (x) A long-term economic impact of colonialism in Africa was
   - A. Self-sufficient economies
   - B. Dependency on cash crops and export-oriented economy
   - C. Industrial dominance
   - D. Abolition of trade

1. (b) Match the items in List A with List B:
   List A
   (i) Berlin Conference
   (ii) Maji Maji Rebellion
   (iii) Indirect rule
   (iv) Pan-Africanism
   (v) Atlantic Charter

   List B
   A. Guided African leaders towards unity
   B. Regulated European colonization
   C. Rebelled against German colonial authority in Tanganyika
   D. Advocated self-determination and freedom after WWII
   E. Governance using local chiefs under colonial supervision

SECTION B (35 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

2. (a) Define *colonialism*.
   (b) Describe two political effects of colonial rule in Africa.

3. (a) Explain two economic policies of European colonial powers.
   (b) Describe one social impact of missionary education.

4. (a) Outline three reasons why African leaders formed nationalist movements.
   (b) Explain one challenge faced by nationalist movements before independence.

5. (a) Describe the Maji Maji Rebellion and its causes.
   (b) Explain the outcome and impact of the rebellion on colonial policy.

SECTION C (45 Marks)
Answer any three questions.

6. (a) Discuss the contribution of Kwame Nkrumah to the independence of Ghana.
   (b) Explain the political strategies he used to achieve independence.

7. (a) Describe the role of Jomo Kenyatta in the struggle for Kenya’s independence.
   (b) Explain how the Mau Mau uprising influenced independence movements.

8. (a) Discuss the impact of European colonization on African economies.
   (b) Suggest two measures post-independence governments took to improve economies.

9. (a) Explain the role of the OAU in conflict resolution among African states.
   (b) Evaluate the successes and limitations of OAU in achieving African unity.

HAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. (a) Multiple choice answers with explanations:

(i) C. To seek trade routes and resources — European exploration was mainly driven by desire for spices, gold, and new trade routes. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz/publications))

(ii) C. Africans captured and sent to the Americas — Millions of Africans were forcibly transported across the Atlantic. ([onlinesys.necta.go.tz](https://onlinesys.necta.go.tz))

(iii) B. African unity and independence — Pan-African Congresses promoted solidarity and independence. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz))

(iv) A. Maji Maji Rebellion — A major anti-colonial uprising against German rule in Tanganyika. ([onlinesys.necta.go.tz](https://onlinesys.necta.go.tz))

(v) B. Using local leaders to govern on behalf of colonial powers — Indirect rule preserved traditional leaders under supervision. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz))

(vi) B. Jomo Kenyatta — Led Kenyan nationalists and later became first President. ([onlinesys.necta.go.tz](https://onlinesys.necta.go.tz))

(vii) B. To spread Christianity and literacy — Missionaries aimed to convert and educate Africans. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz))

(viii) B. Advocated self-determination and freedom — The Atlantic Charter inspired nationalist movements. ([onlinesys.necta.go.tz](https://onlinesys.necta.go.tz))

(ix) B. Introduction of Western education and religion — Colonization altered social structures and belief systems. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz))

(x) B. Dependency on cash crops and export-oriented economy — Colonial economies focused on raw materials for European markets. ([necta.go.tz](https://necta.go.tz))

1. (b) Matching:
(i) B — Berlin Conference regulated European colonization.
(ii) C — Maji Maji Rebellion resisted German rule.
(iii) E — Indirect rule used local chiefs under colonial supervision.
(iv) A — Pan-Africanism promoted African unity.
(v) D — Atlantic Charter advocated self-determination post-WWII.

SECTION B

2.
(a) Colonialism is the control or governing influence of a nation over a dependent country, territory, or people.
(b) Political effects: establishment of foreign administration; loss of sovereignty; introduction of European laws and governance systems.

3.
(a) Economic policies: imposition of cash crops for export; taxation to fund colonial administration.
(b) Social impact: spread of Western education and Christianity, altering traditional beliefs.

4.
(a) Reasons for nationalism: reaction against political domination; economic exploitation; cultural suppression.
(b) Challenge: suppression by colonial authorities, imprisonment of leaders, lack of resources.

5.
(a) Maji Maji Rebellion: 1905–1907 uprising in Tanganyika due to harsh German policies, forced cotton cultivation, and taxation.
(b) Outcome and impact: rebellion suppressed with high casualties, but forced colonial authorities to reconsider some harsh policies.

SECTION C

6.
(a) Kwame Nkrumah: led CPP, mobilized mass movements, advocated for self-governance.
(b) Political strategies: strikes, protests, lobbying, international advocacy, political party formation.

7.
(a) Jomo Kenyatta: led Kenyan African Union, negotiated with British, symbol of nationalist struggle.
(b) Mau Mau uprising inspired independence by demonstrating mass resistance, putting pressure on colonial powers.

8.
(a) European colonization disrupted traditional economies, introduced cash crops, built transport networks for export.
(b) Measures post-independence: diversify economy, develop local industries, reform agriculture.

9.
(a) OAU role: mediate conflicts, promote political cooperation, prevent external interventions.
(b) Successes: prevented major interstate wars, supported liberation movements; Limitations: lacked enforcement power, internal disputes hindered full unity.

ENGLISH.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR CERTIFICATE OF SECONDARY EDUCATION EXAMINATION (CSEE)
022 ENGLISH LANGUAGE
(For both School and Private Candidates)
Time: 3 Hours

Instructions:
1. This paper consists of three sections: A, B and C.
2. Answer all questions in Section A and B, and any three questions from Section C.
3. All answers must be written clearly in the spaces provided.
4. Dictionaries are not allowed.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. Multiple Choice Questions (Choose the correct answer)

   (i) The antonym of 'obscure' is
   - A. Clear
   - B. Dark
   - C. Hidden
   - D. Vague

   (ii) Identify the correct sentence
   - A. He don’t like school.
   - B. He doesn’t likes school.
   - C. He doesn’t like school.
   - D. He don’t likes school.

   (iii) Choose the correct passive form: 'They will finish the work tomorrow.'
   - A. The work will be finished by them tomorrow.
   - B. The work is finished by them tomorrow.
   - C. The work will have finished by them tomorrow.
   - D. The work finished by them tomorrow.

   (iv) Which word is correctly spelled?
   - A. Seperate
   - B. Separate
   - C. Seperete
   - D. Separete

   (v) The meaning of the idiom 'A blessing in disguise' is
   - A. A problem that becomes a good thing
   - B. A visible blessing
   - C. An obvious disaster
   - D. A hidden problem

2. Matching Items

   List A:
   (i) Noun
   (ii) Verb
   (iii) Adjective
   (iv) Adverb
   (v) Pronoun

   List B:
   A. Describes a noun
   B. Shows action or state
   C. Replaces a noun
   D. Names a person, place or thing
   E. Modifies a verb, adjective or adverb

SECTION B (40 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. Read the passage below and answer the questions that follow:

"Education is the key to success. Every child deserves to learn, and education empowers individuals to improve their lives. Schools provide knowledge, skills, and values that help students contribute positively to society."

   (a) What is the main idea of the passage?
   (b) Give two benefits of education mentioned in the passage.

4. Correct the errors in the following sentences:

   (a) She go to market every day.
   (b) I have saw that movie before.

5. Fill in the blanks with the correct form of the word in brackets:

   (a) She is very ___________ (intelligent) student.
   (b) The teacher asked us to ___________ (write) an essay.

6. Write a short letter (about 50 words) to your friend inviting him/her to your birthday party.

7. Rewrite the following sentences in reported speech:

   (a) Mary said, "I am going to the library."
   (b) John said, "I will help you tomorrow."

SECTION C (45 Marks)
Answer any three questions.

8. Write an essay of about 150–200 words on: "The importance of reading books."

9. Write a composition of about 150–200 words describing your favourite season and explain why.

10. Read the following poem and answer the questions:

"The sun sets low, the sky turns red,
The birds return to their cozy bed.
The day is done, the night begins,
Stars appear with twinkling grins."

   (a) What is the theme of the poem?
   (b) Identify two rhyming words in the poem.

11. Write a story of about 150–200 words based on the following beginning: "It was a dark and stormy night when suddenly..."

EAnswers.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple Choice Answers

(i) A. Clear — 'Obscure' means unclear; antonym is clear.
(ii) C. He doesn’t like school. — Correct subject-verb agreement.
(iii) A. The work will be finished by them tomorrow. — Correct passive form.
(iv) B. Separate — Correct spelling.
(v) A. A problem that becomes a good thing — Correct meaning of the idiom.

2. Matching Items

(i) D — Noun names a person, place or thing.
(ii) B — Verb shows action or state.
(iii) A — Adjective describes a noun.
(iv) E — Adverb modifies a verb, adjective or adverb.
(v) C — Pronoun replaces a noun.

SECTION B

3. Reading passage

(a) Main idea: Education is essential for success.
(b) Two benefits: Provides knowledge and skills; empowers individuals to contribute positively to society.

4. Correct the errors

(a) She goes to the market every day.
(b) I have seen that movie before.

5. Fill in the blanks

(a) intelligent
(b) write

6. Short letter sample:

"Dear Friend,
I am excited to invite you to my birthday party on Saturday at 4 pm at my home. There will be food, games, and music. I hope you will come and celebrate with me.
Best wishes,
[Your Name]"

7. Reported speech

(a) Mary said that she was going to the library.
(b) John said that he would help me the next day.

SECTION C

8. Essay sample (short points):
- Reading improves knowledge.
- Enhances vocabulary.
- Stimulates imagination.
- Provides pleasure and relaxation.
- Helps in academic success.

9. Composition sample:
- Favourite season: Rainy season.
- Reasons: Plants grow, cooling effect, enjoyable rain activities, reflection and relaxation.

10. Poem

(a) Theme: Transition from day to night / Nature’s beauty.
(b) Rhyming words: red/bed, begins/grins.

11. Story beginning sample:

"It was a dark and stormy night when suddenly I heard a loud knock at the door. I hesitated but went to open it. To my surprise, a drenched stranger stood there asking for help. I invited him in and offered a warm drink. We talked and shared stories until the storm passed. That night marked the beginning of an unexpected friendship."
